subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Energy outperformed stateside after oil prices were boosted by increased optimism for a deal at tomorrow's OPEC+ meeting
content:
AUSTRALIA

Chorus (CNU AT) - Co. noted that monthly average data usage rose 18% amid lockdown measures. (AFR)

CSL (CSL AT) - Co. affirms FY20 profit guidance and noted no disruption to its supply chains but expects modest delays in capex and clinical trials. (Newswires)

FlexiGroup (FXL AT) - Co. defers interim dividend payment. (Newswires)

G8 Education (GEM AT) - Co. shares halted as it announced to raise AUD 301mln in equity offering and suspends dividends temporarily with final FY19 dividend deferred to October 2020. (Newswires)

Hotel Property Investments (HPI AT) - Co. withdraws FY20 earnings guidance. (Newswires)

Mesoblast (MSB AT) - Co. is to begin trials of Remestemcel-L for treatment of acute respiratory distress caused by coronavirus. (AFR)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) - Co. commits to USD 3.7bln dividend on iron ore demand, while it stated its order books remain full and balance street is song. (Newswires)

Seven West Media (SWM AT) - Co. agreed to revised completion date of May 1st for sale of Pacific Magazines to Bauer Media. (Newswires)

Other News - Australian Parliament passed the AUD 130bln coronavirus wage subsidy bill. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Bic Camera (3048 JT) - Co. cuts FY net profit guidance to JPY 1.8bln from JPY 15.4bln. (Newswires)

Chugai Pharmaceutical (4519 JT) - Co. will begin trials in Japan for its Actemra arthritis drug to treat patients with pneumonia induced by the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. is said to be in discussions with Japanese unions to furlough workers. (Newswires)

Other News 

Tokyo Governor Koike was said to clash with the national government regarding closures as the Governor is said to want the close down of all businesses to contain the coronavirus spread and with the central government wanting to minimize the disruption. (Nikkei)

BoJ is to project an economic contraction which will be the first time it will make such a projection since 2014 amid deepening impact from the coronavirus pandemic, according to sources. The sources added that any projection shouldn’t be too out of line with how the public view the economy, while they suggested there is no consensus yet within the BoJ if the gloomy projection would warrant additional easing. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Ssangyong Motor (003620 KS) - Co. parent Mahindra & Mahindra (MM IS) will not exit from South Korea. (Yonhap)

Geopolitics - Commercial satellite imagery suggested that North Korea conducted a dummy missile ejection at the Sinpo shipyard. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea Finance Minister Hong said they have started to see the virus impact on jobs and expects a surge in the number of applications for employment benefits in March, while he added that they will cut levies for retailers, airlines and tourism sector businesses. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC MINUTES

FOMC Minutes stated all participants viewed the near-term US economic outlook as having deteriorated sharply in recent weeks and as having become profoundly uncertain. Participants judged that it would be appropriate to maintain the FFR at 0.00-0.25% percent until policymakers were confident that the economy had weathered recent events and was on track to achieve the Committee’s maximum employment and price stability goals.

Furthermore, several participants remarked that the public might view the ability of the Committee to provide further monetary policy accommodation as being limited after lowering rates to the ELB. However, this was countered by some by saying new forward guidance or balance sheet measures could be introduced. The minutes added that there was an "extremely large degree" of uncertainty on the outlook and many participants had repeatedly downgraded their outlook of late in response to the rapidly evolving situation. (Newswires)

 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

NIH's Fauci said that beyond this week, US should begin to see a turnaround and that the US is planning to ease back into normal activity if COVID-19 mitigation efforts are successful. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi outlined next stimulus phase and wants a USD 500bln package, while Democrats are to seek USD 250bln in assistance to small businesses, USD 100bln for hospitals, community health centres and health systems, as well as USD 150bln for state and local governments to manage the virus crisis. However, Pelosi also commented that Senate GOP proposals to add money for small business loans will not win unanimous approval in the House and suggested there was no limit to what US can spend for coronavirus in which the US must spend what it needs. (Newswires)

Italy PM Conte said scientists are telling him not to ease lockdown restrictions saying that "we must continue with this rigour". There were also separate reports that France is set to extend virus lockdown in which President Macron will address the nation on Monday and Germany is mulling loosening COVID-19 restrictions after Easter. (Newswires/AFP/Handelsblatt)

UK Deputy Chief Scientific Adviser said the count of new cases is not accelerating out of control and the spread of the virus is not accelerating which is good news. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

China's Financial Stability Committee said it is to strengthen macroeconomic policy and will make prudent monetary policy more appropriate and flexible. (Newswires)

India are reportedly poised to announced INR 1tln stimulus for small businesses and 2nd package would include higher bank loans and tax exemptions for smaller firms, with a separate figure for large business likely as well, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson spokesman said that PM is receiving standard oxygen treatment and is breathing by himself, while the spokesman added that there is no change to the timeline on the lockdown review and that both EU and UK agree that there is scope for further productive discussions on the future relationship. (Newswires)

UK banks are reportedly in talks with the Bank of England regarding new capital relief measures, according to sources. (Newswires)

EU Brexit negotiator Barnier said EC work continues and will speak to UK negotiators next Wednesday to organise upcoming rounds of talks. (Newswires)

ECB's Kazak stated that the ECB can expand and extend the stimulus scheme if needed and can also increase asset purchase volume or even look at new instruments including OMT, while capital key deviations be short-term and operational. (Newswires)

Eurogroup talks will resume on Thursday after having failed to agree on a common text regarding the coronavirus response amid disagreements regarding Netherlands insistence on strict conditions for loans to hard-hit countries like Spain and Italy under the European Stability Mechanism. (Newswires)

France do not rule out debt-issuance initiatives with smaller groups of Eurozone countries in the future, in the event the group cannot come to an agreement, according to a French Presidency Official. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 15.177M vs. Exp. 9.271M (Prev. 13.834M). (Newswires)

Algeria oil minister said the emergency OPEC+ meeting will be "fruitful" and later added that the emergency OPEC++ meeting will discuss a massive reduction in production which could reach 10mln bpd. (Newswires)

Kuwait Oil Minister said that after talking with countries that will attend OPEC+ meeting, intention is moving towards reaching an agreement to lower output by a large amount between 10mln-15mln bpd

Russia is reportedly ready to cut production by 1.6mln BPD, according to Tass citing comments from Russian Energy Minister Novak, while other reports also noted Russia is ready to participate in the OPEC+ deal in line with its share in oil production of countries involved in the deal. (TASS/Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi-led coalition announced there will be 2-week ceasefire in Yemen beginning Thursday following UN calls for a pause in hostilities amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Evans (non-voter, dove) said we are clearly looking at very large losses in employment and output, while he added the economy may begin to be able to recover in the second half of the year if health conditions allow it. Evans also stated that unemployment could reach 20% but could recede in H2 and that it looks like the recession is going to be severe but short-lived. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawk) said it is hard to imagine the US heading back to work until infection numbers drop which could be in May or even later. (Newswires)

US Senator Bernie Sanders suspended his 2020 Democratic Presidential campaign, according to a statement. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

US traders arrived to a cautious risk backdrop, with sentiment hit after European officials could not agree on a way of funding their stimulus package. However, the environment improved, and US stocks opened with cyclical sectors seeing a bounce. However, over the course of the session, the configuration became more mixed, with energy leading the gains, followed by defensive utilities; the bottom end of the pack featured consumer sectors and telecoms; all sectors were green. Attention is on the crude complex ahead of the key OPEC+ call on Thursday; there have been some positive noises suggesting OPEC+ could agree to a 10mln BPD cut; much depends on whether they can convince non-OPEC to join their efforts. Elsewhere, on the virus front, wires reported that investors were encouraged by hopeful signs of the progress of the virus in the US. Health care stocks saw some upside after Bernie Sanders announced he had suspended his Presidential campaign. McDonald’s Corp. (MCD) announced it has suspended share buybacks, is raising USD 6.5bln of debt to strengthen cash position, cuts capex; withdraws 2020 outlook, adding it does not expect March comp sales to be indicative of the nest term. US Comp Sales +0.1%, Comp sales -3.4%, global SSS -22% in March. JPMorgan (JPM) has amended the size of its mixed shelf offering to USD 64.2bln (prev. USD 50bln). Boeing (BA) found two new software issues with its 737 MAX flight control computers, according to CNBC; the Co stated the plan for the jet to return to the skies by the middle of this year and would not be delayed due to this. Note, fuselage provider Spirit AeroSystems (SPR) announced it has temporarily stopped producing for BA given the closure of Boeing facilities. SPX +3.4% at 2750, NDX +2.2% at 8230, DJIA +3.4% at 23,434.

Treasuries endured a choppy session, although ranges have been thinner and major curve spreads are ultimately steeper, lead by a strong bid at the 2-year tenor, while yields along the long-end are higher on the day. The T-Note had originally seen support in early European trade as the Eurogroup meeting failure induced risk-off. However, participants soon looked past the news amid a bid in equity futures, and yields moved higher. Duration also came under pressure after Treasury Sec. Mnuchin doubled-down on its plans for issuance out the curve, citing the (yet-to-be-released) 20-year bond, again. Corporate supply was also weighted towards the long-end across six IG issuers (although less than Monday and Tuesday), in addition to Abu Dhabi launched USD 7bln of 5s, 10s, and 30s. As the NY Fed’s daily operations got underway, the whole curve found support, and steepened, rising in sync with equities, and richening ahead of the Treasury’s upsized 30-year auction reopening, where USD 17bln was sold at a high rate of 1.325%, stopping through by 0.5bps, and was covered 2.35x; Dealers and indirects took a bit more than average at the expense of less direct participation (11% vs six-auction avg. 17.7%). By settlement, yields were mixed; worth noting in the rates complex, the white strip of Eurodollar curve was little changed, indicative of participants expectations of LIBOR to remain elevated for the near future. However, UBS’ strategists expressed their view recently that they see the rate normalising in the next month or so. US T-note futures (M0) settled 2 ticks lower at 137-27.

subject: US House Speaker Pelosi says Republican's proposals to add money for small business loans will not win unanimous approval in the House; Pelosi says no limit to what US can spend, must spend what it needs
Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 8th: Risk ends firmer as stocks and oil climb ahead of OPEC++
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries mixed, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: Fed minutes stale, note deep uncertainty; Eurogroup meeting to resume on Thursday after Tuesday failure; positive OPEC+ ramblings while US inventories print record builds.
  • COMING UP: Data: German Trade Balance, UK GDP, US Initial Jobless Claims, Canadian Employment, US University of Michigan. Events: RBA Financial Stability Review, OPEC+ Meeting Begins, Eurogroup Meeting Resumes & ECB Minutes. Speakers: Fed’s Powell. Supply: Italy. Note: Desk will operate as normal until 21:30BST on Thursday, before closing for the entirety of Friday’s Good Friday market holiday.

MARKET WRAP 

US traders arrived to a cautious risk backdrop, with sentiment hit after European officials could not agree on a way of funding their stimulus package. However, the environment improved, and US stocks opened with cyclical sectors seeing a bounce. However, over the course of the session, the configuration became more mixed, with energy leading the gains, followed by defensive utilities; the bottom end of the pack featured consumer sectors and telecoms; all sectors were green. Attention is on the crude complex ahead of the key OPEC+ call on Thursday; there have been some positive noises suggesting OPEC+ could agree to a 10mln BPD cut; much depends on whether they can convince non-OPEC to join their efforts. Elsewhere, on the virus front, wires reported that investors were encouraged by hopeful signs of the progress of the virus in the US.   

VIRUS CASE COUNT

WORLDWIDE CASES 1,497,999, DEATHS 87,731, RECOVERED 319,192. 

Figures provided as of Wednesday (via worldometer website) against Tuesday: 

  • US total cases 422,369 (prev. 400,335), death toll 14,463 (prev. 12,841).
  • ITALY total cases 139,442 (prev. 135,586), death toll 17,669 (prev. 17,127).
  • SPAIN total cases 146,690 (prev. 141,942), death toll 14,673 (prev. 14,045).
  • GERMANY total cases 110,698 (prev. 107,663), death toll 2,192 (prev. 2,016).
  • CHINA total cases 81,802 (prev. 81,740), death toll 3,333 (prev. 3,331).
  • FRANCE total cases 112,950 (prev. 109,069), death toll 10,869 (prev. 10,328).
  • UK total cases 60,733 (prev. 55,242), death toll 7,097 (prev. 6,159).
  • SWITZERLAND total cases 23,248 (prev. 22,253), death toll 895 (prev. 821)
  • NETHERLANDS total cases 20,549 (prev. 19,580), death toll 2,248 (prev. 2,101).
  • CANADA total cases 19,183 (prev. 17,897), death toll 427 (prev. 381).
  • SOUTH KOREA total cases 10,384 (prev. 10,331), death toll 200 (prev. 192).

Note figures are provided via worldometer thus there may be some discrepancies on figures provided against those stated from individual states.  

EUROPE 

EUROGROUP: The Eurogroup failed to reach an agreement on Tuesday and cancelled their press conference as ministers were unable to reach consensus on a common text. Eurogroup head Centeno tweeted, “After 16h of discussions we came close to a deal but we are not there yet”. The finance ministers will continue their meeting on Thursday. The Dutch Finance Minister tweeted that the use of the ESM has not been agreed, but the Netherlands are prepared to use it; also, reiterated opposition to Eurobonds, indicated that a majority of members are in agreement on this. To wit, Morgan Stanley believes the Eurogroup will ultimately come to a deal on Centeno’s previously outlined, three-prong proposal: 1) ESM precautionary credit lines of up to 2% of GDP (around EUR 240bln vs the EUR410bn current ESM lending capacity), which MS believes in order to be attractive for the periphery, due to their higher borrowing costs, the lines would have to offer long duration with limited conditionality; 2) an increase in contributions to the EIB to support loan guarantees, which MS says could support around EUR 200bln of loans; 3) an increase in member state support to back the Commission’s EUR 100bln unemployment re-insurance scheme (SURE) which gets behind member state schemes to pay capped salaries to furloughed workers. More broadly, MS sees the package as “further support”, citing the ECB’s PEPP as the key policy to address the crisis due to it keeping yields low, and thus, greater fiscal policy space.  

STIMULUS: The European Commission has warned EZ Finance Ministers that the EU economy could shrink by up to 10% in 2020; sources added that the ECB told ministers that EZ financing required could be up to EUR 1.5trln to address the virus crisis. However, sources reported Germany supports just EUR 500bln worth of measures at this stage. Furthermore, the FT reported the Commission is discussing proposals to overhaul the EU budget to bolster the post-pandemic recovery, which could result in an extra EUR 1.5trln for spending and investment over three years. 

 UK PM JOHNSON: PM Johnson remains in intensive care, though is making steady progress, a statement noted.   

LOCKDOWN: The chief French government medical advisor said France’s confinement measures should be extended for several weeks.  

NORTH AMERICA  

STIMULUS: President Trump said he would ask Congress for an additional USD 250bln in small businesses relief, coming after the Treasury asked for an additional USD 250bln for the small business lending programme.  

LOCKDOWN: VP Pence said evidence continues to show signs of stabilisation in virus hot spots and that the CDC will have new guidance on Wednesday regarding quarantining and how individuals can return to work. President Trump said the US is being hit hard, and it will be a painful week, but also noted there are glimmers of hope and that the country may be on track for far fewer deaths than projected, as well as maybe getting to the top of the virus curve. Trump noted they are starting to look at reopening the economy very thoroughly, which will be open again much sooner rather than later, he said.   

GEOPOLITICS: While President Trump initially stated the US is going to put a hold on contribution to the WHO, noting the group is China-centric and disagreed with his travel ban, he since said the US would look into holding off funding. On the Middle Eastern front, WSJ reported the US is planning to block Iran’s request for a USD 5bln loan from the IMF to deal with the coronavirus.  

CENTRAL BANKS

FOMC MINUTES: Minutes to the Fed’s emergency meetings on 3rd and 15th meetings were always going to have a stale feel about them, given that the central bank took further actions after the meeting (boosted QE and MBS purchases on 23/Mar, expanded repo for foreign central banks on 31/Mar, and also announced six additional facilities, including the commercial paper facility). As expected, the minutes highlighted the Fed’s uncertainty, and all participants viewed the near-term outlook as having deteriorated sharply. The minutes also conveyed that officials were fearful of the outlook, even before the stay-at-home orders were issued. The minutes also reiterated now-familiar themes about how rates will remain at current levels until the Fed can be confident that the situation has turned. BMO’s analysts note that the word ‘plummet’ made four appearances, ‘uncertain’ showed up nine times, ‘deteriorated’ on six occasions, but ‘recession’ only once. “There was no discussion of the massive job losses sustained last month - which makes sense given the spike in initial jobless claims printed after the FOMC’s last gathering.” BMO also highlights a section of the minutes that reveals an in-depth discussion about Treasury market liquidity which helps justify the scale and depth of the UST purchases that began in March, although conditions have improved since then. BMO also highlights that there were no answers to some outstanding questions: “There was no discussion about how the Fed might taper it’s QE flows, whether or not they might hike the ON RRP rate and IOER in the near term,” adding that “things have simply changed so much in the past three weeks that those topics weren’t even on the table.”  

ECB’S KAZAK stated that the ECB could expand and extend the stimulus scheme if needed, can increase asset purchase volume, or even look at new instruments, including OMT. Kazak said capital key deviations would be short-term and operational.  

DATA  

INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS PREVIEW: Last week’s jobless claims saw a record of 6.65mln jobs, with expectations for this weeks print likely to be somewhere similar with analysts expecting a print of 5.25mln, although the ranges vary from as low as 2.5mln to 9.295mln on the top end. Continued jobless claims expected at 8mln; ranges from 2.054mln to 13.2mln. Bank of America is expecting to see another 6.5mln print. The bank tracked headlines in 16 states which it estimates to be around 2.5mln, thus assuming a similar trend it would take the total to 6.5mln. BofA however believes that risks are tiled to the upside after seeing an increase in data from Google Trends shows an increase in searches for unemployment benefits and filing for unemployment, while it notes there were signs governments are adjusting to better process the filings, adding “some states believed the worst was yet to come”. The desk also highlights the passing of the CARES act and Coronavirus Aid Relief increases eligibility for jobless claims for other workers and boost the maximum number of weeks that one can receive benefits. The desk adds this creates an incentive for businesses to temporarily furlough employees as they will be financially covered. However, seasonal factors could have an impact, “combining last week’s non-seasonally adjusted figure of 5.8mln with this week’s lower seasonal factor would result in seasonally adjusted claims of 6.2mln instead of 6.6mln that was actually reported.”  

CRUDE 

WTI (K0) SETTLES USD 1.46 HIGHER AT USD 25.09/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLES USD 0.97 HIGHER AT USD 32.84/BBL 

Crude prices were firmer, although trade was choppy, with a late session spike higher into settlement amid reports that the Algerian Oil Minister sees a massive reduction at the “OPEC++” production at Thursday’s meeting of 10mln BPD; taken at face value, this might imply total coordinated cuts above 10mln, if other non-OPEC+ producers come to the table. A delegate overnight noted that scenarios range from 10mln BPD of output curtailment to no cuts at all. The OPEC+ group’s monitoring committee is said to be preparing a draft for proposed output cuts. Several sources have noted that the following two scenarios will be presented: 1) OPEC+ no longer being bound by production restrictions; this would see a continuation of the current state of affairs - Saudi would stick to its current production quota in excess of 12mln BPD (vs 9.7mln BPD in March). 2) OPEC members alongside Russia and other producers would implement joint 10mln BPD reductions through to the end of the year (TASS on Tuesday reported a time-frame of three months starting in May). Tass also reported later on Wednesday that Russia is ready to cut production by 1.6mln BPD. Meanwhile, Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh stated in a letter to OPEC that Iran doesn’t agree with holding an OPEC+ meeting without having a clear and consensual outcome. At the same time, he added that vague circumstances around the OPEC+ meeting are of grave concern to him and that the absence of any clear outcome is a failure message, even before the meeting starts, which may aggravate current low oil prices further. Furthermore, Zanganeh stated that the volume of an output cut, duration, baseline level and distribution, as well as commitments by the US and Canada, should be addressed before the meeting.   INVENTORIES: US crude inventories saw some brief selling pressure as the EIA reported a record build of 17.2mln bbls, accompanied by a 10.5mln build in gasoline and 0.5mln distillates build, as refinery utilisation dropped by a significant 6.7% and production fell from 13mln BPD to 12.4mln BPD. The eye-watering figures were mainly looked through as participants are well aware of the production cuts and storage limits as the global economy has come to a standstill.  

OPEC+(+) PREVIEW: Emergency Meeting on Thursday; G20 Energy Meeting on Friday. On Thursday, the OPEC+ meeting is to commence at 15:00BST, followed by a press conference - all times tentative. On Friday, G20 Energy Ministers will conduct a webinar at 13:00BST to discuss oil market stability. Click here for the full Newsquawk preview.        

FIXED INCOME  

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 2 TICKS LOWER AT 137-27.  

Treasuries endured a choppy session, although ranges have been thinner and major curve spreads are ultimately steeper, lead by a strong bid at the 2-year tenor, while yields along the long-end are higher on the day. The T-Note had originally seen support in early European trade as the Eurogroup meeting failure induced risk-off. However, participants soon looked past the news amid a bid in equity futures, and yields moved higher. Duration also came under pressure after Treasury Sec. Mnuchin doubled-down on its plans for issuance out the curve, citing the (yet-to-be-released) 20-year bond, again. Corporate supply was also weighted towards the long-end across six IG issuers (although less than Monday and Tuesday), in addition to Abu Dhabi launched USD 7bln of 5s, 10s, and 30s. As the NY Fed’s daily operations got underway, the whole curve found support, and steepened, rising in sync with equities, and richening ahead of the Treasury’s upsized 30-year auction reopening, where USD 17bln was sold at a high rate of 1.325%, stopping through by 0.5bps, and was covered 2.35x; Dealers and indirects took a bit more than average at the expense of less direct participation (11% vs six-auction avg. 17.7%). By settlement, yields were mixed; worth noting in the rates complex, the white strip of Eurodollar curve was little changed, indicative of participants expectations of LIBOR to remain elevated for the near future. However, UBS’ strategists expressed their view recently that they see the rate normalising in the next month or so. 

EQUITIES  

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +3.4% at 2750, NDX +2.2% at 8230, DJIA +3.4% at 23,434.  

SECTORS: Real Estate +7.4%, Energy +6.7%, Utilities +5.4%, Materials +5%, Health Care +4.2%, Industrials +3.65, Consumer Discretionary +2.84%, Communication Svs. +2.8%, Technology +2.75%, Consumer Staples +1.4%  

STOCK SPECIFICS: Health care stocks saw some upside after Bernie Sanders announced he had suspended his Presidential campaign. McDonald’s Corp. (MCD) announced it has suspended share buybacks, is raising USD 6.5bln of debt to strengthen cash position, cuts capex; withdraws 2020 outlook, adding it does not expect March comp sales to be indicative of the nest term. US Comp Sales +0.1%, Comp sales -3.4%, global SSS -22% in March. JPMorgan (JPM) has amended the size of its mixed shelf offering to USD 64.2bln (prev. USD 50bln). Boeing (BA) found two new software issues with its 737 MAX flight control computers, according to CNBC; the Co stated the plan for the jet to return to the skies by the middle of this year and would not be delayed due to this. Note, fuselage provider Spirit AeroSystems (SPR) announced it has temporarily stopped producing for BA given the closure of Boeing facilities. Tesla (TSLA), Dick’s (DKS) and Party City (PRTY) are to furlough workers. Marathon Oil (MRO) and Holly Frontier Corp. (HFC) cut CapEx. TAL Education (TAL) were hit after an internal report found some if its “Light Class” sales had been fabricated; its Light Class sales make up 3-4% of total revenue. E-Health (EHTH) was named as a new short. Health Insurers benefited on news Bernie Sanders has dropped out of the presidential campaign given he is an advocate for Medicare for all. Zoom Video (ZM) surged after reports it has hired a former Facebook security chief to improver its privacy, which follows recent weakness in the name as it faces lawsuits for inadequate security.  

FOREX 

USD: The buck was marginally stronger overnight, though has deviated little from neutral. The Eurogroup failed to come to an agreement on how to fund the coronavirus stimulus bill, the press conference has been postponed until Thursday at 16:00 BST. However, as US players arrived sentiment improved which led to a firmer equity open and some reversal in the buck to unchanged levels which coincides around the 100 level on DXY. That 100 level has held as the Asia day comes into focus.   

EUR: The Eurogroup’s failure to strike a stimulus deal has soured sentiment, while growth projections from the Bank of France also contributed to caution in the early part of trade. EURUSD was slightly weaker against the buck today and gave up the 1.09 figure following the stale mate in talks, while France extending its lockdown did little to benefit the single currency. ING believes the impact will be limited as expectations are not high for a coronabond and currently the fiscal risk premium is not a main driver of the EUR, adding that the stabilising risk apetite should slow dollar appreciation.   

JPY: The economy watcher’s survey was grim, falling to a record low; Capital Economics said it supports its view that consumption will fall off a cliff in Q2. “Almost all indicators plummeted, suggesting the brief thaw in economic activity in mid-March was swiftly ended by a devastating cold front.” Household inflation expectations one-year ahead fell to 2.0% from 2.5%. USDJPY fairly uneventful today trading within 108-52-109-09 parameters, with the cross relatively flat heading into overnight trade.  

AUD: AUD initially weaker overnight after S&P cut its outlook on Australia to AAA; outlook negative from stable, while citing downside and fiscal risks. RBC highlights the rationale for the downgrade is not particularly surprising and S&P are right to highlight the risks due to the uncertainty on the trajectory on both domestic and global economy while domestic factors such as historically high household debt are also a concern. It said however that its own GDP expectations for Australia were much weaker than S&P’s. In an international context, AU is still better placed than many others to deliver the fiscal stimulus (and has already announced measures that go well beyond its G10 counterparts)”. However, as sentiment improved the cyclical currency reversed course and reclaimed 0.62 to the upside.  

NZD: In similar price action to its Antipodean counterpart, NZD was lower overnight spurred by dovish comments from RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby noting the bank is open to expanding its QE in a rapidly evolving situation, noting there is no limit to how much of the bond market it can buy, adding it is considering other assets for QE, including linkers. The comments saw NZDUSD hit lows of 0.5940 although picked up steam in similar vein to AUD as risk sentiment improved which saw the cross reclaim 0.60 to the upside.   

CAD: The Loonie slightly weaker today against the buck remaining above the 1.40 region heading into overnight trade while CAD losses are limited amid a rise in oil prices, While comments from Canadian officials note that businesses now only need to show a 15% drop in March revenue Y/Y (prev. 30%) to receive the 75% wage subsidy. Participants will be looking to tomorrows employment report. Scotiabank states “We prefer to look for opportunities to fade USD gains to the 1.4150/75 range.”  

GBP: Sterling is firmer on the day, in line with other risk sensitive FX, and cable lingers around 1.24 as Asia day begins. Analysts at Lloyds suggest the pullback from 1.25 is a correction before a move higher to 1.27 and perhaps north of 1.33, from a technical perspective, although if a move beneath 1.2165 occurred it would become a worry for the bulls and opens the door to support at 1.2025 -1.1950.  

BRL: BCB chief Campos Neto late Tuesday said the central bank was looking at measures for both big and small companies. This morning Neto noted the BCB stands ready to intervene in FX more aggressively than it has ever done, adding although Brazil has a free-floating FX regime, the central bank will act when volatility or FX moves are out of line or disorderly. Neto noted that most stimulus in other countries accounts to 6-7% of GDP, he stated this is a high figure and we have to “see what happens”. The Lower House will today vote on proposals to vote on expanded coronavirus relief measures.  

MXN: The Banxico minutes release saw little reaction to the Peso, but the currency continued to appreciate against the dollar likely benefitting from firmer oil prices ahead of tomorrow’s OPEC+ call. The Banxico minutes showed all members noted the world economy and growth outlook deteriorated rapidly and significantly, while some argued possibility of a global recession has increased but one pointed towards an economic recovery next year. The minutes also highlighted the moves from the Federal reserve, and the Banxico have previously kept an eye on US interest rates.

subject: TREASURY WRAP: US T-Note Futures (M0) Settle 2 ticks lower at 137-27
analysis_details: Treasuries endured a choppy session, although ranges have been thinner and major curve spreads are ultimately steeper, lead by a strong bid at the 2-year tenor, while yields along the long-end are higher on the day. The T-Note had originally seen support in early European trade as the Eurogroup meeting failure induced risk-off. However, participants soon looked past the news amid a bid in equity futures, and yields moved higher. Duration also came under pressure after Treasury Sec. Mnuchin doubled-down on its plans for issuance out the curve, citing the (yet-to-be-released) 20-year bond, again. Corporate supply was also weighted towards the long-end across six IG issuers (although less than Monday and Tuesday), in addition to Abu Dhabi launched USD 7bln of 5s, 10s, and 30s. As the NY Fed’s daily operations got underway, the whole curve found support, and steepened, rising in sync with equities, and richening ahead of the Treasury’s upsized 30-year auction reopening, where USD 17bln was sold at a high rate of 1.325%, stopping through by 0.5bps, and was covered 2.35x; Dealers and indirects took a bit more than average at the expense of less direct participation (11% vs six-auction avg. 17.7%). By settlement, yields were mixed; worth noting in the rates complex, the white strip of Eurodollar curve was little changed, indicative of participants expectations of LIBOR to remain elevated for the near future, although UBS’ strategists expressed their view recently that they see the rate normalising in the next month or so.

subject: WTI (K0) settles USD 1.46 higher at USD 25.09/bbl; Brent (M0) settles USD 0.97 higher at USD 32.84/bbl
analysis_details:
• Crude prices were firmer, although choppy with a late session spike higher into settlement, amid OPEC+ production cut ramblings and firmer risk appetite seen in equities. The late session rally coincided with some optimistic comments from the Algerian Oil Minister in Argus, suggesting a massive reduction at the “OPEC++” meeting that could reach 10mln BPD. A delegate overnight noted that scenarios range from 10mln BPD of output curtailment to no cuts at all. The OPEC+ group’s monitoring committee is said to be preparing a draft for proposed output cuts. Several sources, via Energy Intel, note two scenarios will reportedly be presented: 1) The first scenario sees OPEC+ no longer being bound by production restrictions. This set-up would see a continuation of the current state of affairs - Saudi would stick to its current production quota in excess of 12mln BPD (vs 9.7mln BPD in March). 2) In the second scenario, OPEC members alongside Russia and other producers would implement joint 10mln BPD reductions through to the end of the year (TASS on Tuesday reported a time-frame of three months starting in May). Tass also reported later on Wednesday that Russia is ready to cut production by 1.6mln BPD. Meanwhile, Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh stated in a letter to OPEC that Iran doesn’t agree with holding an OPEC+ meeting without having a clear and consensual outcome. At the same time, he added that vague circumstances around the OPEC+ meeting are of grave concern to him and that the absence of any clear outcome is a failure message, even before the meeting starts, which may aggravate current low oil prices further. Furthermore, Zanganeh stated that the volume of an output cut, duration, baseline level and distribution, as well as commitments by the US and Canada, should be addressed before the meeting. Meanwhile, US crude inventories saw some brief selling pressure as the EIA reported a record build of 17.2mln bbls, accompanied by a 10.5mln build in gasoline and 0.5mln distillates build, as refinery utilisation dropped by a significant 6.7% and production fell from 13mln BPD to 12.4mln BPD. The eye-watering figures were mainly looked through as participants are well aware of the production cuts and storage limits as the global economy has come to a standstill.
  • OPEC+(+) PREVIEW: Emergency Meeting on Thursday; G20 Energy Meeting on Friday. On Thursday, the OPEC+ meeting is to commence at 15:00BST, followed by a press conference - all times tentative. On Friday, G20 Energy Ministers will conduct a webinar at 13:00BST to discuss oil market stability. Click here for the full Newsquawk preview.

FOMC Minutes: All participants viewed the near-term US economic outlook as having deteriorated sharply in recent weeks and as having become profoundly uncertain
content:
On Policy:

  • Several participants remarked that the public might view the ability of the Committee to provide further monetary policy accommodation as being limited after lowering rates to the ELB. However, this was countered by some by saying new forward guidance or balance sheet measures could be introduced.
  • Several participants commented that banks should be discouraged from repurchasing shares from, or paying dividends to, their equity holders in the wake of the proposed measures.
  • Participants judged that it would be appropriate to maintain the FFR at 0 to ¼ percent until policymakers were confident that the economy had weathered recent events  and was on track to achieve the Committee’s maximum employment and price stability goals.

Economic Outlook:

  • An "extremely large degree" of uncertainty on the outlook
  • Many participants had repeatedly downgraded their outlook of late in response to the rapidly evolving situation.
  • All saw US economic activity as likely to decline in the coming quarter and viewed downside risks to the economic outlook as having increased significantly.
  • Participants noted that the timing of the resumption of growth in the US economy depended on the containment measures put in place, as well as the success of those measures, and on the responses of other policies, including fiscal policy.

PRIMER: FOMC Meeting Minutes to be released at 1400 ET/1900 BST on 8th April 2020 [REPOST]
content:
• On the 3rd March, the Fed cut rates by 50bps in an emergency move. And then on 15th March weekend meeting, the Fed took further aggressive steps, slashing rates by 100bps to 0.25% in its second inter-meeting rate move; it also committed to at least USD 700bln of QE, eased regulatory pressure on banks to free up capital, and announced dollar swap lines with other central banks.  
  • The timing of the both announcements and the scope of the measures was a surprise -- in effect, it was the Fed's 'whatever it takes' commitment to ensure the smooth functioning of markets amid the virus fallout.  
  • NOTE: It is not clear whether the release of the minutes will cover both meetings, or just the latter; it is also unclear that if the minutes do cover both meetings, whether the release will be in two separate documents, or one aggregated one. Analysts at Nomura, however, have stated that the minutes will cover actions taken at both meetings. 
  • Since then, it has flooded the market with liquidity, resulting in the premium for dollars easing. Its balance sheet has ballooned to by USD 1.5trln to a new record high USD 5.86trln, and it has seen wide take-up of its liquidity facilities from banks and other central banks.  
  • The meeting minutes are unlikely to contain anything to spook markets, given that it has rolled-out measures to assuage market concerns, and will likely reiterate its pledge to support the financial system. Analysts think the discussions will likely show a most participants backing the use of the Fed's toolkit aggressively, as COVID-19 outbreak began weighing on activity.  
  • The minutes may, however, feel stale. Since the 15th March meeting, the Fed has announced other measures (boosted QE and MBS purchases on 23/Mar, expanded repo for foreign central banks on 31/Mar, and also announced six further facilities, including the commercial paper facility). Discussions around these themes will likely appear in the next meeting minutes for the 28-29th April meeting, analysts believe. 
  •  NOTE: Fed Chair Powell will be delivering remarks via weblink on Thursday, and will likely emphasise the themes within the minutes.

content:
THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: Treasury supply this week consists of a new 3-year note (Mon, USD 40bln), re-opening a 10-year note (Tue, USD 25bln) and a 30-year bond (Thu, USD 17bln).   

30-YEAR PREVIEW: The prior auction was weak, and resulted in a tail of 4bp. SocGen thinks the 30-year sector looks rich on asset swap, noting that although the 5s30s curve had steepened meaningfully after the last month's 30-year auction, it retraced most of the move and is currently slightly above the level before the March 30-year reopening. It also points out that the current WI yield for the sector is trading close to the stop-out yield of the March reopening. “A rich outright valuation may deter some investors from participating in the auction,” SocGen writes, “relatively high dealer holdings in the 11-years+ sector imply that dealers have limited ability to absorb supply.”

Daily FX Wrap: muddling midweek session, but scope for more clarity from Thursday
content:
USD

A whip-saw Wednesday for the Dollar and currency markets overall as risk sentiment waxed and waned ahead of potentially pivotal pre-Easter events in the form of delayed OPEC+ and Eurogroup meetings. The DXY has been holding above the psychological 100.000 mark for the most part, but not convincingly and may be cautious ahead of upcoming FOMC minutes before a more timely update on the state of the US economy from Fed chair Powell tomorrow.

GBP/AUD/NZD

Sterling has notched a new wtd high vs the Greenback just a whisker shy of 1.2400 and remains firm across the board following the latest encouraging medical report on UK PM Johnson who is in a stable condition and responding well to treatment. However, the Aussie and Kiwi have both arguably performed even better amidst faltering risk appetite and independent weights, such as S&P revising its outlook to negative from stable for the still triple AAA rated sovereign and ANZ’s even more downcast business sentiment reading respectively. Indeed, Aud/Usd posted a fresh, albeit fractional peak over 0.6200 in recent trade and Nzd/Usd rebounded from sub-0.5950 to a few pips above 0.6000 before topping out again.

CAD

Although crude prices have not recoiled on the back of another considerably bigger than expected US weekly inventory build in anticipation of the oil cartel and other major global producers reaching agreement on a quota cut, the Loonie is lagging its US counterpart and all G10 rivals in wake of Canadian housing data showing weaker starts and permits prior to the real fallout from COVID-49. Usd/Cad has duly retraced further from Tuesday’s circa 1.3945 trough and firmly back on the 1.4000 handle in advance of March’s jobs report that is widely forecast to be bleak in keeping with US NFP last Friday.

JPY/CHF/EUR

The Yen has largely retained an underlying safety premium above 109.00 in the run up to Thursday’s likely game-changers, unlike the Franc that remains caught between bouts of Buck strength and Euro weakness on more pronounced nCoV contagion plus the lack of coordinated fiscal Eurozone action. Hence, Usd/Chf is pivoting 0.9700, while Eur/Chf hugs 1.0550 and Eur/Usd lags nearer the bottom of 1.0902-1.0831 parameters.

EM

Aside from wider risk considerations and the Dollar’s ongoing gyrations, regional Central Bank impulses have been influential for the Pln, Czk and Brl in particular. To recap, the NBP defied consensus with blanket 50 bp benchmark rate cuts, Czech Parliament approved a bill to provide the CNB with a QE mandate and the BCB signalled more aggressive currency intervention.

Banxico meeting minutes: All members pointed out that the world economy and its growth outlook deteriorated rapidly and significantly as a result of the COVID-19 outbreak
content:
• All members pointed out that the world economy and its growth outlook deteriorated rapidly and significantly as a result of the COVID-19 outbreak.
  • Most members agreed that the isolation measures adopted have contributed to the halt in economic activity, to supply chain disruptions, and to a decline of global demand.
  • Some argued that the possibility of a global recession in 2020 has increased, while one pointed out that, in general, a recovery is expected for next year.
  • Among the risks to world economic activity, most members highlighted a greater-than-expected spread of COVID-19.
  • All members mentioned that the prices of commodities, especially of crude oil, have plummeted. 
  • Most members underlined that this is due to the observed and anticipated reduction in demand and to disputes among the main oil producers.
  • All members mentioned that different central banks in advanced and emerging economies lowered their interest rates, in some cases ahead of schedule. 
  • Most members mentioned that the US Federal Reserve held two unscheduled meetings, in which it cut the federal funds rate by a total of 150 basis points, down to a range of 0-0.25%. 
  • Such members pointed out that, globally, other extraordinary monetary measures have also been implemented to mitigate the effects of the expected fall in domestic and external demand, and to guarantee the well-functioning of financial markets. 
  • In particular, they highlighted the measures to provide liquidity and incentivise credit, as well as the purchase programs of the following assets: i) government bonds; ii) mortgage-backed securities; iii) corporate bonds; iv) non-financial firms’ commercial papers; v) equity funds, and vi) real estate investment funds.
  • Via Banxico

US STOCK OPEN: US indices firmer amid a turnaround in risk sentiment from the morning; all sectors green, defensives underperform
analysis_details:
MACRO: The situation was calm in Asia though soured as the Europeans arrived amid headlines noting the lack of progress by finance ministers in striking a stimulus deal. Asian stocks outside of Japan, Taiwan and NZ were lower, and European bourses are also trading on the soft side. Gold is higher, crude is slightly firmer, and yields along the Treasury curve are mixed, though there seems to be a bias towards a steeper curve.  

MARKET FOCUS: The market's focus is firmly on Eurogroup and OPEC; the former are trying to thrash out a mega stimulus deal in response to coronavirus - the Europeans could announce stimulus worth 5% of the bloc's GDP, which would help to stabilise sentiment, and possibly result in equity inflows; the latter is attempting to engineer a coordinated global supply cut deal to boost crude prices. Both are key events worth keeping on equity trader's radars - crude has been playing a significant role in equity sentiment, particularly around the 1430 ET settlement.  

VIRUS: While many have been focusing on the easing pace of new cases, we noted earlier in the week that the focus may shift towards the death rate, and signs of any second wave reinfections. Analysts at Citi today follow-up on that theme, stating that the market will be paying more attention to rising death rates even as infections slow; the bank notes that the lockdown on Wuhan was lifted, which has resulted in tens of thousands leaving the city to disperse across China -- the risk of reinfection is one to watch closely. It is worth noting NIH’s Fauci has stated that beyond this week, the US should begin to see a turnaround and that the US is planning to ease back into normal activity if COVID-10 mitigation efforts are successful.  

SECTOR THEMES: Of note for retailers who have benefitted from the panic stockpiling of goods as the coronavirus pandemic broke out, today Tesco (TSCO LN) provided an update noting the initial bout of panic buying has subsided, and sales are returning to a normal pace. Some desks highlight that if the sales were to return to normal for other retailers, on both sides of the pond, it could act as a headwind as the panic buying slows down. It is also worth highlighting ahead of the Easter holiday that footfall is likely to be down heavily given the current lockdowns and store closures. All sectors in positive territory with defensives the relative under performers, while energy leads the pack today. 

US EQUITY STORIES: McDonald's Corp. (MCD) announced it has suspended share buybacks, is raising USD 6.5bln of debt to strengthen cash position, cut capex; and withdrew its 2020 outlook, adding it does not expect March comp sales to be indicative of the nest term. US Comp Sales +0.1%, Comp sales -3.4%, global SSS -22% in March. JP Morgan (JPM) has amended the size of its mixed shelf offering to USD 64.2bln (prev. USD 50bln). Boeing (BA) found two new software issues with its 737 MAX flight control computers, according to CNBC; the Co stated the plan for the jet to return to the skies by the middle of this year and would not be delayed due to this. Note, fuselage provider Spirit AeroSystems (SPR) announced it has temporarily stopped producing for BA given the closure of Boeing facilities. Tesla (TSLA), Dick’s (DKS) and Party City (PRTY) are to furlough workers. Marathon Oil (MRO) and Holly Frontier Corp. (HFC) cut CapEx.  

BEAR MARKET RALLY: Nomura says the stock market rally seen at the start of the week was led by exits from bearish trades, including a squeeze on short positions held by systematic traders. "Most investors (apart from some with short investment horizons) are still in standby mode, and some may be inclined to sell whatever rallies come along," the bank's quant desk writes, "the pick-up in investor sentiment looks like no more than the sort of spontaneous rebound in sentiment that one would normally expect under the circumstances," adding that we should view this rally as nothing more than an "unenthusiastic, inorganic bear market rally." Its quants say that the key technical indicator is CTAs' net positions in NASDAQ 100 futures (it appears that CTAs were quick to swing long on NASDAQ 100 futures), which can be read as a leading indicator of what may happen in other equity futures markets. For the next week or two, it is critical to examine "whether the CTAs that are currently driving the rally manage to smoothly pass the baton to fundamentals-oriented investors without anyone dropping it." Nomura says that, should the baton get dropped, it expects CTAs' net buying of NASDAQ 100 futures to wind down by 22 April.  

LIQUIDITY: Note, as the market holiday on Friday and Monday approaches, trading may become a function of liquidity, volatility and positioning, Goldman Sachs has said. Liquidity is expected to taper-off as the holidays approach, which could make for choppy trading conditions amid possible macro headline risk.

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

April 8th 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • Of note for retailers (WMT, CLX), Tesco (TSCO LN) provided an update this morning noting the initial bout of panic buying has subsided, and sales are returning to a normal pace. Some desks highlight that if the sales were to return to normal for other retailers, on both sides of the pond, it could act as a headwind as the panic buying slows down. It is also worth highlighting ahead of the Easter holiday that footfall is likely to be down heavily given the current lockdowns and store closures.

DOW JONES

  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) found two new software issues with its 737 MAX flight control computer, according to CNBC, who note the Co stated the plan for the jet to return to the skies by the middle of this year and would not be delayed due to this.
  • Intel Corp. (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) is reportedly going to introduce its 10th-generation desktop processor next month, according to DigiTimes citing motherboard makers, who expect an improvement in Q2 sales.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) is reportedly halting any new hires apart from those in strategic areas, according to Business Insider.
  • United Health Group Inc. (UNH) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) announced it would immediately accelerate payments to health care providers in the US to help against short term financial pressure amid COVID-19.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) will reportedly pause its delivery service for non-Amazon packages, according to WSJ citing people familiar with the matter. The move reportedly comes as it re-evaluates the nascent offering that competes with FedEx (FDX) and UPS (UPS).
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) will reportedly temporarily reduce employees salaries and to furlough non-essential workers as it has been forced to suspend vehicle production amid COVID-19 but plans to restart production on May 4th, according to CNBC.

S&P 500

  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) – Juul Labs. Co-founder is to leave the company this week, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) announced the US FDA accepted its SBLA for Opdivo plus Yervoy for treatment of patients with metastatic or recurrent non-small cell lung cancer.
  • CME Group Inc. (CME) (Financials/Financial Exchanges & Data) Q1 20 international ADV 7.2mln contracts, +57% Y/Y (outside US).
  • HollyFrontier Corp (HFC) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) announced it is reducing CapEx by roughly 15% to USD 525-625mln (prev. 623-729mln).
  • Marathon Oil Corp. (MRO) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) announced it cut its 2020 CapEx budget by USD 1.1bln to USD 1.3bln.
  • Occidental Petroleum (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) announced it opposes the Texas oil and gas regulators production limits.
  • Perrigo (PRGO) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) Q1 20 (USD): Preliminary revenue 1.3bln (exp. 1.26bln), adj. operating income 220-225mln.
  • PVH Corp. (PVH) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) announced it is to furlough roughly 75% of its store, office and warehouse associates or decrease their hours, Co has suspended its share repurchases and cash dividend from Q2 while drawing down USD 750mln from its USD 1bln revolving credit facility.

OTHER

  • Air Lease (AL) (Industrials/Trading Companies & Distributors) Q1 update: Fleet of 301 owned aircraft and 82 managed, with 399 new aircraft orders from Boeing (BA) and Airbus (AIR FP, EADSY), set to deliver through to 2026. In Q1, it delivered eight new aircraft, acquired 1- A330-300 and sold three jets to Thunderbolt Aircraft Lease. Sale proceeds roughly USD 65mln.
  • Annaly Capital (NLY) (Financials/Mortgage Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) in a letter to shareholders reiterated its strong position and stressed how its portfolio had seen improved liquidity and valuations due to Federal Reserve actions, it now expects to see core earnings between USD 0.2-0.21/shr (prev. 0.26).
  • Dick’s Sporting Goods (DKS) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) is to furlough a number of its workers from April 12th, adding it will provide health benefits throughout the leave.
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) is reportedly in talks with unions about restarting production in Italy after the government removes the restrictions in place.
  • Levi Strauss (LEVI) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.40 (exp. 0.35), revenue 1.51bln (exp. 1.47bln). Announced it suspended its share repurchase programme and withdrawn its FY20 guidance.
  • Party City (PRTY) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) is to furlough 90% of its employees and 70% of those who work in other functions but will continue to receive health benefits.
  • Pinterest (PINS) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) announced it has withdrawn its FY20 guidance, but its preliminary numbers for the March quarter saw revenue between USD 269-272mln (exp. 267mln).
  • Spirit Aerosystems (SPR) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced it has halted Boeing (BA) production programmes, subject to certain exceptions, following the suspension of production at Boeings Washington and South Carolina factories.
  • Square (SQ) (Information Technology/IT Services) CEO, Jack Dorsey, announced he is moving USD 1bln of his Square equity to fund global COVID-19 relief.
  • TAL Education (TAL) (Consumer Discretionary/Diversified Consumer Services) announced following a routine internal audit. It suspects an employee wrongly inflated its “Light Class” sales, which accounts for 3-4% of its revenue for FY20 ending February 29th.
  • Zoom Video (ZM) (Information Technology/Software) has been accused of overstating privacy standards and failing to make adequate disclosures regarding its security in a class-action lawsuit, according to CNBC. Elsewhere, the German Foreign Ministry has restricted the use of its app over security concerns, according to Handelsblatt.

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Rises as EU Fails to Reach Agreement on Debt
content:
•   USD picks up slightly amid negative tilt to market mood on failure of EU talks.
  •   CAD crosses above 1.40 mark again as oil prices falter.
  •   EUR weakens as EU fails to reach COVID-19 financing agreement.
  •   GBP outperforms with no new (bad) news on PM’s health.
  •   JPY posts modest decline but remains in high 108s.
  •   AUD unchanged despite downgrade to credit rating outlook.
  •   MXN rebounds from negative risk tone in early hours, flat for the session.

subject: China Politburo says China is facing increasing difficulties in economic development; says China will expand domestic demand and boost consumption
EU antitrust regulators are to allow generic drug makers to temporarily cooperate to supply critical hospital medicines
Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment was hit early doors on the Eurogroup being postponed, US futures currently little changed
  • Eurogroup President Centeno confirmed talks will resume tomorrow with no deal reached yet and cancelled today’s press-conference
  • Core debt futures flew on Centeno’s remarks as peripheries sunk along with EUR/USD; albeit, the latter has fought back
  • US President Trump said he will ask Congress for an additional USD 250bln in small businesses relief
  • Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh stated in a letter to OPEC that Iran doesn't agree with holding any OPEC+ meeting without having a clear and consensual outcome
  • Looking ahead, highlights include DoEs, FOMC & Banxico Minutes, supply from the US

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US President Trump said the US is being hit hard now and it will be a painful week but also noted we see glimmers of hope and that the US may be on track for far fewer deaths than projected, as well as may be getting to the top of the coronavirus curve. President Trump added they are starting to look at reopening the economy very thoroughly which will be open again much sooner rather than later, while he initially stated the US is going to put a hold on contribution to the WHO and noted they were China centric and disagreed with his travel ban, but later stated we will look at holding off funding. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he will ask Congress for an additional USD 250bln in small businesses relief and there were earlier reports that the US Treasury is preparing to ask Congress for an additional USD 200bln for the small business lending programme according to sources. (Newswires/Washington Post)

US VP Pence said we continue to see evidence of stabilization in coronavirus hot spots and that the CDC will have new guidance on Wednesday regarding quarantining and how someone can return to work. (Newswires)

Hong Kong extended social distancing measures to April 23rd from April 11th, while it ordered the closure of beauty parlours and massage facilities. (Newswires/Xinhua) Hong Kong is to offer in excess of HKD 100bln in a new relief package, according to SCMP.

France's COVID-19 confinement measures should be extended for several weeks, according to the Head of the French Medical Advisers to the Government. (Newswires)

Spanish coronavirus cases 146,690 (Prev. 140,510) and deaths stand at 14,555 (Prev. 13,798); deaths increase by 757 (Prev. increase 743). (Newswires)

ASIA

A tentative tone was observed in Asia-Pac bourses following the lacklustre performance stateside where all major indices finished with marginal losses after the initial risk on tone eventually lost steam ahead of looming key risk events including the conclusion of the Eurogroup deliberations and tomorrow’s OPEC+ meeting. ASX 200 (-0.8%) traded choppy with the early heavy losses in Australia triggered by weakness across the top-weighted financials sector after the regulator issued guidance on banks and insurers in an effort to restrict dividends and with sentiment also dampened after S&P cut the outlook on the country’s AAA sovereign rating to negative from stable, although the index later shrugged off the losses as the sentiment improved in late trade, while the Nikkei 225 (+2.1%) was also indecisive for most the session after the cabinet approved a record JPY 108tln stimulus package and declared a month-long state of emergency as expected. Hang Seng (-1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) conformed to the early cautious tone in the region amid PBoC liquidity inaction but with downside stemmed after the State Council continued to outline supportive measures and after outbound travel restrictions were lifted from Wuhan which was the former epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded back above the 152.00 level but with price action rangebound amid the indecision in Japan and following a tepid Rinban announcement in which the BoJ are present in the market for a total of JPY 670bln of JGBs in 1-3yr and 5-10yr maturities with the amounts unchanged from prior operations.      

PBoC skipped open market operations for a met neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0483 vs. Exp. 7.0483 (Prev. 7.0939)

UK/EU

EuroGroup head Centeno tweeted: 'After 16h of discussions we came close to a deal but we are not there yet'; suspended the Eurogroup which will continue on Thursday. Also confirmed the press conference (originally scheduled for 0900BST) was cancelled.

-        The Dutch Finance Minister tweeted that the use of the ESM has not been agreed, but the Netherlands are prepared to use it; also, reiterates that they are against Eurobonds, indicates a majority of EZ countries are in agreement on this

-        European Commission has reportedly warned EZ Finance Ministers that the EU economy could shrink by up to 10% in 2020; sources added that the ECB told ministers that EZ financing could be up to EUR 1.5tln to address the virus crisis; however, sources reported Germany supports EUR 500bln worth of measures at this stage.

EU Commission is discussing proposals to overhaul the EU budget to bolster post-pandemic recovery which could result in an extra EUR 1.5tln for spending and investment over 3-years. (FT)

ECB's Kazak states that the ECB can expand and extend the stimulus scheme if needed, ECB can increase asset purchase volume or even look at new instruments including OMT, capital key deviations be short-term and operational. (Newswires)

EU have reportedly introduced tariffs of up to 18.9% on stainless steel products emanating from China, Indonesia and Taiwan - to last for a period of 6-months. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US plans to block Iran's request for USD 5bln loan from the IMF to deal with the coronavirus. (WSJ)

EQUITIES

The risk tone across Europe took a turn for the worse after Eurozone Finance Ministers yesterday failed to agree on the stimulus measures to deploy in light the coronavirus crisis. Italy noted that it will reject a final report sent to EU leaders unless debt mutualisation is mentioned as a tool whilst also demanding no conditional attachments to the ESM loans. Netherlands reiterated their objection Eurobonds and intimated a majority agree on this. Price action this morning saw futures sliding off following reports of the impasse in talks, and confirmation via Eurogroup President Centeno of the delay. European cash markets are subdued by circa 1.0-2.0% across the region (Euro Stoxx 50 -1.4%). Sectors are mostly in the red with underperformance seen in Energy amid yesterday’s losses in the complex, whilst Financials also bear the brunt of the Eurogroup deadlock and lower yield environment. Looking at the breakdown, Oil and Gas are the laggards whilst Travel & Leisure continue to feel some reprieve. In terms of individual movers, Tui (+3.5%) leads the early doors gains in the Stoxx 600 after the Co. confirmed the signing of EUR 1.8bln state aid bridge loan. Tesco (-5.0%) shares remain in negative territory after the Co. noted that COVID-19 is having a material impact on business and the group is incurring significant additional costs. The estimated impact is seen on retail cost lines seen between GBP 650-925mln. Commerzbank (-6.4%) remains near the bottom of the pan-European index after reports the sale of its Polish unit mBank could be delayed amid the virus crisis

Chinese retail passenger car sales -36% Y/Y in March, according to prelim data. (Newswires)

UK banks are reportedly in talks with the Bank of England regarding new capital relief measures, sources state. (Newswires)

FX

AUD/NZD/CAD - The Aussie has reversed further from Tuesday’s post-RBA peaks in wake of S&P’s ratings review that came with a sting in the tail as the agency downgraded its outlook on the sovereign’s AAA standing. Aud/Usd is back below 0.6150 vs 0.6200+ when broad risk sentiment was still buoyant and its Antipodean peer was also outpacing the Usd on the 0.6000 handle compared to just under 0.5950 currently. In terms of Kiwi specifics, RBNZ Deputy Governor underlined the severity of the COVID-19 contagion overnight by stating that QE can be expanded to include other assets like linkers given that the pool of conventional bonds that can be purchased is limited. Elsewhere, the Loonie has lost 1.4000+ status after failing to test sub-1.3950 resistance ahead of Canadian housing data and against the backdrop of idling crude prices awaiting tomorrow’s OPEC+ showdown.

EUR/CHF/GBP - All on a weaker footing against the US Dollar as risk appetite wanes, but with the Euro also undermined by the Eurogroup’s failure to resolve differences on a coordinated fiscal response to the coronavirus even though dire economic predictions continue to unfurl, ie French Q1 GDP -6% per the BdF and Germany contracting almost 10% in the current quarter according to leading institutes. Eur/Usd holding between 1.0902-1.0831 parameters and perhaps propped by an array of decent option expiries stretching from 1.0800 to 1.0900 – full details available via the headline feed at 7.33BST. Meanwhile, the Franc is skirting 0.9700, but retaining an underlying safe-haven premium relative to the single currency as the cross hovers around 1.0550 and Sterling is also somewhat mixed awaiting more UK nCoV updates and progress reports from hospital where PM Johnson remains in intensive care. Cable is clinging to 1.2300 and Eur/Gbp is meandering in the low 0.8800 area, well above 1.5 bn expiry interest from 0.8700 to 0.8710.

JPY/DXY - The Yen and Buck are still jostling for position amidst fluctuating risk-on/off phases, with Usd/Jpy confined to narrow 109.00-108.50 extremes and the index not much more adventurous in advance of weekly US mortgage applications and FOMC minutes either side of 100.00, albeit with a firmer bias on balance up to 100.430 at best.

SCANDI/EM - A general loss of momentum alongside risk assets overall, and with the Nok perhaps acknowledging another dip in Norwegian inflation plus a pretty stark prognosis from the Stats office about the scale of non-oil growth for the month of March alone (-14%). However, the Zar has regained composure and is trying to resume its recovery mission from record lows following some rare positive news from Eskon claiming it has enough funding for 2020 and will not need more cash from the Government.

S&P cut Australia sovereign Outlook to Negative from Stable; affirmed AAA rating. (Newswires)

RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said the central bank was open to expanding QE in a rapidly evolving situation and noted there is a limit to how much of the bond market the RBNZ can buy but they are considering other assets for QE including linkers. (Newswires)

FIXED

Core debt remains firmly underpinned, but off best levels as stocks and oil pare worst declines and sentiment in general settles down. However, Gilts are holding above 136.00 and nearer the top of the Liffe range following yet more well received cash auctions vs Bunds hovering closer to their Eurex base (170.64 vs 171.31 at one stage) even though 10 year German issuance was also absorbed comfortably. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are flat-lining and rather side-lined ahead of a pretty sparse US agenda aside from FOMC minutes that may be deemed somewhat stale already.

COMMODITIES

Choppy price action is seen in the energy complex in the run-up to arguably the most OPEC+ meeting to date. A delegate overnight noted that scenarios range from 10mln BPD of output curtailment to no cuts at all. The OPEC+ group’s monitoring committee is said to be preparing a draft for prospective output cuts. Several sources via Energy Intel note two scenarios will reportedly be presented: 1) The first scenario sees OPEC+ no longer being bound by production restrictions. This set-up would see a continuation of the current state of affairs - Saudi would stick to its current production quota in excess of 12mln BPD (vs. 9.7mln BPD in March) 2) In the second scenario, OPEC members alongside Russia and other producers would implement joint 10mln BPD reductions through to the end of the year, whilst TASS yesterday reported a time-frame of three months. Elsewhere, last night’s APIs proved to be another bearish release, with inventories building 11.9mln barrels vs. Exp. build of 9.3mln. Albeit, prices remained locked onto OPEC headlines. The release of the EIA STEO (ahead of next week’s OPEC and IEA Oil Market Reports) encapsulated the March impact of COVID-19, the agency cut 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 5.6mln BPD to 5.23mln BPD and raised 2021 forecast by 4.68mln BPD to 6.41mln BPD. Nonetheless, WTI and Brent front-month futures are now mixed after sentiment was hit by news of a roadblock among EZ finance ministers on a stimulus package for the bloc. WTI outperforms its Brent counterpart with the former currently residing around USD 24.50/bbl, having had earlier topped its 21DMA (USD 24.98/bbl) to a high of USD 25.29/bbl in overnight trade. Brent meanwhile briefly dipped below USD 32.00/bbl having earlier tested resistance at USD 33/bbl (intraday high). Elsewhere, spot gold remains steady and within a relatively narrow USD 1640-57/oz intraday band. Copper prices meanwhile wiped out mild overnight gains as risk sentiment deteriorated after reports EZ finance ministers failed to reach a consensus on EU-wide stimulus to combat COVID-19. The red metal looks to retest its 21DMA to the downside at USD 2.25/lb.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (Apr 3) +11.9mln Vs. Exp. +9.3mln (Prev. +10.5mln). (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh stated in a letter to OPEC that Iran doesn't agree with holding any OPEC+ meeting without having a clear and consensual outcome, while he added that vague circumstances around OPEC+ meeting is of grave concern to him and that the absence of any clear outcome is a failure message even before the meeting starts which may aggravate current low oil prices further. Furthermore, he stated that volume of output cut, duration, baseline level and distribution of cuts, as well as cuts by US and Canada should be addressed prior to the meeting. (Newswires)

OPEC+ monitoring committee is preparing a draft for prospective output cuts, according to RIA. Separately, Russia's Kremlin declines to signal Russia's position for tomorrow's OPEC+ meeting. (Newswires)

Two Republican senators who have introduced a bill into the Senate, which is aimed at withdrawing troops and defense systems from Saudi Arabia, in the event the nation does not reduce oil output, are set to host a call with kingdom officials on Saturday, according to sources. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs said OPEC is no longer a price-setter in the shale age but has a key role in managing inventories and setting shape of the oil forward curve, while it added that OPEC+ short-term market share maximization strategy is counterproductive but OPEC's long-term market share gains are inevitable. (Newswires)

analysis_details:
Reminder: 

  • Russian producers are reportedly ready for oil cuts in order to stop the price rout, where the industry may agree to cuts if US and Saudi joins
  • Russia is not likely to agree to output cuts if US does not also curb production, according to sources cited by WSJ's Summer Said
  • Russia and Saudi Arabia are reportedly 'very, very close' to a deal on oil production cuts, according to Dmitriev the CEO of RDIF
  • Saudi Arabia and Russia are reportedly coming closer to an agreement on an output deal, according to delegates but there reportedly is no consensus between Russia and Saudi Arabia as of yet, all will be decided at Thursday's OPEC+ meeting, according to RIA's Novosti
  • Russia held off on hiking output in April amid the supply glut
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak said current oil price is not satisfying for anyone, but Moscow can survive through a period of low prices

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 17bln of 30-year bonds at 1300 ET/1800 BST on Wednesday 8th April 2020
content:
THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: Treasury supply this week consists of a new 3-year note (Mon, USD 40bln), re-opening a 10-year note (Tue, USD 25bln) and a 30-year bond (Thu, USD 17bln).

30-YEAR PREVIEW: The prior auction was weak, and resulted in a tail of 4bp. SocGen thinks the 30-year sector looks rich on asset swap, noting that although the 5s30s curve had steepened meaningfully after the last month's 30-year auction, it retraced most of the move and is currently slightly above the level before the March 30-year reopening. It also points out that the current WI yield for the sector is trading close to the stop-out yield of the March reopening. “A rich outright valuation may deter some investors from participating in the auction,” SocGen writes, “relatively high dealer holdings in the 11-years+ sector imply that dealers have limited ability to absorb supply.”

RECENT 30-YEAR AUCTION HISTORY:

  • High yield: (prev. 1.32%, six-auction avg. 2.105%)  
  • Tail: (prev. 4bps, six-auction avg. 0.1bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.36x, six-auction avg. 2.38xx) 
  • Dealers: (prev. 21.6%, six-auction avg. 19.8%) 
  • Direct: (prev. 8.9%, six-auction avg. 17.7%)   
  • Indirect: (prev. 69.5%, six-auction avg. 62.5%)

subject: ECB allots USD 5.9bln in its 7-day operation

ECB's Kazak states that the ECB can expand and extend the stimulus scheme if needed, ECB can increase asset purchase volume or even look at new instruments including OMT, capital key deviations be short-term and operational
analysis_details:
• For reference, Kazak is the Latvian representative
  • Outright Monetary Transactions were not formally discussed at the latest ECB meeting but it was brought up, with sources noting that there is broad support of activating it in time of crisis
  • This will allow the ECB to buy almost unlimited amounts of govt debt from stressed-EUR area countries
  • Some analysts have suggested that the OMT programme has already been made redundant by the ECB's new PEPP; the final sentence of the ECB's PEPP statement last Wednesday reads stated that "the ECB will not tolerate any risks to the smooth transmission of its monetary policy in all jurisdictions of the euro area" - on the same day, Italy's central bank was reportedly purchasing bonds to maintain monetary transition.
  • Furthermore, OMTs have a duration of three years, whereas PEPP bonds will indefinitely stay on the European Central Bank's balance sheet - thus spreading the cost of borrowing over a longer horizon and keeping annual costs subdued.
